lesson_title: The Logic Gate: Mastering the Conditional Particle ば (ba)
lesson_summary: In this lesson, we will learn how the particle ば (ba) functions as a logical connector. By attaching to the verb bases you've already mastered—the Unrealized (Mizenkei) and the Realized (Izenkei)—it creates 'If/Then' and 'Because/When' relationships.

grammar_explanation.concept: The particle ば (ba) is a 'conjunctional particle' that links two clauses. Its meaning changes strictly based on the 'state' of the verb base it attaches to, acting like a boolean logic gate in programming.
grammar_explanation.formation: 1. [Mizenkei (Unrealized)] + ば = Hypothetical ('If X happens...'). 2. [Izenkei (Realized)] + ば = Deterministic ('Since/When X happened...').
common_confusions: In Modern Japanese, 'ba' is almost always hypothetical. In Classical Japanese, however, it is most frequently used with the Izenkei to mean 'because' or 'when'.

teaching_sequence.content: You have already learned the 'Unrealized Base' (Mizenkei) for things that haven't happened and the 'Realized Base' (Izenkei) for things that have. Think of these bases as 'data types.' The particle ば (ba) is the operator that processes them. If you feed it an 'Unrealized' base, it outputs a hypothetical 'If.' If you feed it a 'Realized' base, it outputs a factual 'Since' or 'When.' In the following poems, we will see the 'Realized' version in action, where an observation leads directly to a poetic realization.

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>田子<rt>たご</rt></ruby>の<ruby>浦<rt>うら</rt></ruby>にうち<ruby>出<rt>い</rt></ruby>でて<ruby>みれば<rt>みれば</rt></ruby><ruby>白妙<rt>しろたえ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>富士<rt>ふじ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>高嶺<rt>たかね</rt></ruby>に<ruby>雪<rt>ゆき</rt></ruby>は<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>りつつ
display.romaji: tagono ura ni uchi idete mireba shirotae no fuji no takane ni yuki wa furitsutsu
display.translation: When I go out to the shore of Tago and look, I see the snow is falling on the high peak of Fuji, pure white.

vocabulary.chinese_cognate_note: Same meaning as '浦' in Chinese (e.g., 黄浦江)

vocabulary.meaning: to go out / to set out
to see/look (Izenkei/Realized base of 見る)

vocabulary.chinese_cognate_note: 高 = high, 岭 = mountain ridge

teaching_sequence.content:
Look at the word **みれば (mireba)**. It is composed of the verb **みる (miru - to see)** in its **Izenkei (Realized Base)** form **みれ (mire)**, plus the particle **ば (ba)**. 

Because the 'seeing' is a realized fact (the poet has already looked), the logic is: 
`[Fact: I looked] + ば = 'When I looked...'` or `'Because I looked...'` 

This creates a sequence of events: First, the act of looking is completed, and then the discovery of the snow on Fuji follows.

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>大江山<rt>おおえやま</rt></ruby>いく<ruby>野<rt>の</rt></ruby>の<ruby>道<rt>みち</rt></ruby>の<ruby>遠<rt>とお</rt></ruby>ければまだふみもみず<ruby>天<rt>あま</rt></ruby>の<ruby>橋立<rt>はしだて</rt></ruby>
display.romaji: ooe yama iku no no michi no tookere ba mada fumi mo mizu ama no hashidate
display.translation: Because the road to Ikuno via Mount Oe is so far, I have not yet seen a letter from my mother, nor have I set foot at Amanohashidate.

vocabulary.chinese_cognate_note: 大 = big, 江 = river, 山 = mountain

vocabulary.meaning: to go / also part of place name 'Ikuno'
subject marker (in this context, 'the road is...')
is far (Izenkei/Realized base of 遠し)

teaching_sequence.content:
In the second poem, we see **遠ければ (tookereba)**. 
1. **遠けれ (tookere)** is the Izenkei (Realized) form of the adjective 'far'. 
2. **ば (ba)** follows it. 

Logic: `[Fact: The road is far] + ば = 'Because the road is far...'` 

Compare this to the hypothetical (Mizenkei + ba) which we haven't seen in these poems yet: 
If the poet said **遠かば (tookaba)** [Mizenkei + ba], it would mean **'If it were far...'** (but it might not be). But here, the distance is a reality, so we use the Izenkei.

display.text_with_furigana: <ruby>天<rt>あま</rt></ruby>の<ruby>原<rt>はら</rt></ruby>ふりさけ<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>れば<ruby>春日<rt>かすが</rt></ruby>なる<ruby>三笠<rt>みかさ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>山<rt>やま</rt></ruby>に<ruby>出<rt>い</rt></ruby>でし<ruby>月<rt>つき</rt></ruby>かも
display.romaji: ama no hara furisake mireba kasuga naru mikasa no yama ni ideshi tsuki kamo
display.translation: When I look up at the plain of heaven, I see the moon that has come out over Mount Mikasa in Kasuga.

vocabulary.meaning: the plain of heaven / the sky
to look up / to look far (Izenkei)

teaching_sequence.question: In Poem 3, the poet uses '見れば' (mireba). Based on what you've learned about the Izenkei (Realized Base), why is 'when/since' a better translation than 'if'?
teaching_sequence.answer: Because 'mire' is the Izenkei (Realized Base), indicating the act of looking has actually occurred. The poet is currently looking at the sky and seeing the moon, so it's a factual observation ('When I look'), not a hypothetical scenario ('If I were to look').
teaching_sequence.hint: Think about whether the poet is actually looking at the moon right now or just imagining looking at it.

reference_card.one_liner: A logical connector that means 'If' when attached to the Unrealized Base (Mizenkei) and 'When/Because' when attached to the Realized Base (Izenkei).
reference_card.example: 見れば (mire-ba) = When/Since I look; 見ば (mi-ba) = If I look.

forward_references.note: This emotional exclamation at the end of Poem 3 will be covered in Unit 10: Sentence-Final Particles.
The 'shi' here is the past tense marker we touched on in Unit 5; we will see how it interacts with nouns in the next unit.
